title: Drow (starting race)

**Drow**, sometimes known as "dark elves", are a playable [race](/wiki/Race "Race") of [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") that appears in some [variants](/wiki/Variant "Variant") of *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. They are most commonly implemented as a type of [elf](/wiki/Elf_\(monster_attribute\) "Elf (monster attribute)") that are dark counterparts to standard [elves](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)"), with a similar spread of [attribute](/wiki/Attribute "Attribute") caps.

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

*"dNetHack section still has stuff to sift through. SLASH'EM item subs as well"*

## SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), drow serve as [chaotic](/wiki/Chaotic "Chaotic") same-race counterparts to the elves:[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) the elves of SLASH'EM are usually lawful and can be played as lawful or neutral, as opposed to being chaotic like in *NetHack*. Drow can take the roles of [Barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian"), [Flame Mage](/wiki/Flame_Mage "Flame Mage"), [Ice Mage](/wiki/Ice_Mage "Ice Mage"), [Necromancer](/wiki/Necromancer "Necromancer"), [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest"), [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger"), [Undead Slayer](/wiki/Undead_Slayer "Undead Slayer"), or [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard").

According to the [Guidebook](/wiki/Guidebook "Guidebook"):

Drow are the dark elves of the sunless realm. Well-suited to the dungeon environment, they have much in common with standard elves, but their specialty is their sleep attack.

### SLASH'EM benefits and restrictions

- *For other qualities of drow monsters (including the hero) in this variant, see [Drow (monster attribute)#SLASH'EM](/wiki/Drow_\(monster_attribute\)#SLASH.27EM "Drow (monster attribute)").*

A drow hero engaging in [bare-handed combat](/wiki/Bare-handed_combat "Bare-handed combat") can sometimes put [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster") to [sleep](/wiki/Sleep "Sleep"), and like elves they gain [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance") at [experience level](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level") 4.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) Unlike elves, drow heroes do not have [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision") and cannot be seen via infravision themselves, and they are also incapable of [two-weapon combat](/wiki/Two-weapon_combat "Two-weapon combat").

#### SLASH'EM attribute caps

| [Str](/wiki/Strength "Strength") | [Dex](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity") | [Con](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") | [Int](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") | [Wis](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") | [Cha](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") |
| -------------------------------- | ---------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | ---------------------------- | -------------------------------- |
| 18                               | 18                                 | 16                                       | 20                                       | 20                           | 18                               |

Like elves in SLASH'EM, drow excel in mental attributes and are tied for the highest [intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") and [wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") caps at 20, while their [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") has the lowest cap at 18, tied with elves and hobbits. Drow are also tied with elves for the lowest [constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") cap at 16.

### SLASH'EM strategy

The drow's sleep-inducing bare-handed attack make them enticing for players new to SLASH'EM: during the early game, drow characters survive well if they know when to fight bare-handed, and can keep monsters asleep with repeated strikes - this also enables them to more effectively fight multiple opponents or flee into a corridor as necessary. Drow heroes with high bare-handed combat [skill](/wiki/Skill "Skill") and fortunate enough rolls can even take down [shopkeepers](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper") in hand-to-hand battles without taking a hit. The trade-off for this remarkable power is the lower damage output imposed by the inability to two-weapon, as well as the limits on attribute shared with standard elves.

A droven [Barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian") is an easy race-role combination that allows the player to begin fighting bare-handed before switching to a better weapon like a [battle-axe](/wiki/Battle-axe "Battle-axe") or an [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon").

## dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), drow have several substantial differences from elves, when begins as early as starting alignment: female drow heroes start the game as chaotic, while male drow or "hedrow" heroes are neutral. The [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") a drow hero undertakes also differs between genders as well, and is also dependent on their role.

Drow can take the role of [Anachrononauts](/wiki/Anachrononaut "Anachrononaut"), [Binders](/wiki/Binder "Binder"), [Convicts](/wiki/Convict "Convict"), [Healers](/wiki/Healer "Healer"), [Madpeople](/wiki/Madpeople "Madpeople"), [Nobles](/wiki/Noble "Noble"), [Pirates](/wiki/Pirate "Pirate"), [Priests](/wiki/Priest "Priest"), [Rogues](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue"), [Rangers](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger"), [Troubadours](/wiki/Troubadour "Troubadour"), or [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard").

### dNetHack benefits and restrictions

- *For other qualities of drow monsters (including the hero) in this set of variants, see [Drow (monster attribute)#dNetHack](/wiki/Drow_\(monster_attribute\)#dNetHack "Drow (monster attribute)").*

Drow can see perfectly in the dark, but cannot see into lit areas and are virtually 'blind' in the light: light-blindness is much different from ordinary [blindness](/wiki/Blindness "Blindness") in that a drow hero can still see (and thus will not have intrinsic [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy") trigger), but can only see items and [engravings](/wiki/Engraving "Engraving") directly at their feet, along with items in their own inventory. Drow heroes can create a patch of darkness using the [#monster](/wiki/Monster_\(command\) "Monster (command)") [extended command](/wiki/Extended_command "Extended command"), which costs up to 10 [energy](/wiki/Energy "Energy") (or all of it if their maximum energy is below 10).

Drow heroes, and nearly all drow monsters except for any of the [Changed](/wiki/Changed "Changed"), are generated as belonging to a particular "house" - this can usually be determined by the house symbols engraved on signet rings and heavy droven armor. Drow from houses that are aligned against each other will be mutually hostile, and will be hostile towards a drow hero of an opposing faction - conversely, drow of the same house, or of different houses that are aligned with each other, will be peaceful towards each other and towards drow heroes of allied factions.

All drow heroes can reach Grand Master skill level in bare-handed combat.

The default starting [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") for a drow hero has a 2⁄3 chance of being a [cave spider](/wiki/Cave_spider "Cave spider"), and will otherwise be a [baby cave lizard](/wiki/Baby_cave_lizard "Baby cave lizard"). Drow Healers instead start with a tame [knight](/wiki/Knight_\(player_monster\) "Knight (player monster)"); hedrow Nobles start with a [saddled](/wiki/Saddled "Saddled") [small cave lizard](/wiki/Small_cave_lizard "Small cave lizard"), while female drow Nobles start with a saddled [giant spider](/wiki/Giant_spider "Giant spider").

#### dNetHack attribute caps

| [Str](/wiki/Strength "Strength") | [Dex](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity") | [Con](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") | [Int](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") | [Wis](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") | [Cha](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") |
| -------------------------------- | ---------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | ---------------------------- | -------------------------------- |
| 18                               | 20                                 | 16                                       | 20                                       | 18                           | 20                               |

Drow and elves share similar attribute caps, including boosted dexterity (20 compared to 18 in *NetHack*), but exchange their higher wisdom for higher charisma.

### dNetHack starting equipment

Drow have several replacements made to the starting equipment of their [role](/wiki/Role "Role"), and often have different starting inventories between genders - their starting inventory may also differ outright from that of other races playing the same role.

| Standard item(s)                                     | Replacement item(s)                                                         | Affected roles                                                                                             |
| ---------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| [robe](/wiki/Robe_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Robe (SLASH'EM)")  | [droven plate mail](/wiki/Droven_plate_mail "Droven plate mail")            | [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest")                                                                            |
| [athame](/wiki/Athame "Athame")                      | [droven dagger](/wiki/Droven_dagger "Droven dagger")                        | [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard")                                                                            |
| [dagger](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger")                      |                                                                             | [Noble](/wiki/Noble "Noble"), [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger"), [Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue")                |
| [knife](/wiki/Knife "Knife")                         | [droven crossbow](/wiki/Droven_crossbow "Droven crossbow")                  | [Pirate](/wiki/Pirate "Pirate")                                                                            |
| [short sword](/wiki/Short_sword "Short sword")       | [droven short sword](/wiki/Droven_short_sword "Droven short sword")         | [Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue")                                                                               |
| [bow](/wiki/Bow "Bow")                               | [droven crossbow](/wiki/Droven_crossbow "Droven crossbow")                  | [Noble](/wiki/Noble "Noble"), [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger")                                              |
| [arrow](/wiki/Arrow "Arrow")                         | [droven bolt](/wiki/Droven_bolt "Droven bolt")                              | [Noble](/wiki/Noble "Noble"), [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger")                                              |
| [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace")                            | [droven greatsword](/wiki/Droven_greatsword "Droven greatsword")            | [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest") (male only)                                                                |
|                                                      | [khakkhara](/wiki/Khakkhara "Khakkhara")                                    | [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest") (female only)                                                              |
| [buckler](/wiki/Buckler "Buckler")                   | [droven helm](/wiki/Droven_helm "Droven helm")                              | [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest")                                                                            |
| [leather cloak](/wiki/Leather_cloak "Leather cloak") | [droven chain mail](/wiki/Droven_chain_mail "Droven chain mail")            | [Troubadour](/wiki/Troubadour "Troubadour")                                                                |
| [apple](/wiki/Apple "Apple")                         | [tripe ration](/wiki/Tripe_ration "Tripe ration")                           | [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight"), [Noble](/wiki/Noble "Noble"), [Troubadour](/wiki/Troubadour "Troubadour") |
| [torch](/wiki/Torch "Torch")                         | [shadowlander's torch](/wiki/Shadowlander%27s_torch "Shadowlander's torch") | [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger"), [Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue")                                              |
| [quarterstaff](/wiki/Quarterstaff "Quarterstaff")    | [khakkhara](/wiki/Khakkhara "Khakkhara")                                    | [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") (female only)                                                              |

All drow heroes start with a [droven signet ring](/index.php?title=Droven_signet_ring\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Droven signet ring (page does not exist)"), which is a [randomized appearance](/wiki/Randomized_appearance "Randomized appearance") for [rings](/wiki/Ring "Ring") that allows the ring to function as a means of injecting poison poison-injection rings: when [dipped](/wiki/Dipped "Dipped") into an eligible [potion](/wiki/Potion "Potion"), the ring absorbs 30 doses of poison, which can be inflicted on opponents by attacking them in bare-handed combat while wearing the ring; if two signet rings are worn, both apply their poison. A drow hero's staring signet rings are pre-loaded with [sleeping](/wiki/Sleep "Sleep") poison, and will always be of a valid ring type for their role. Signet rings also bear specific crests, sometimes including the silvered holy symbols of drow deities: rings that have a spiderweb design on them add +5 to unarmed attacks, while rings with holy symbols count as silver rings when attacking silver-hating monsters.

Droven weapons have higher base damage than most starting weapons, and are made of [obsidian](/index.php?title=Obsidian_\(dNetHack\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Obsidian (dNetHack) (page does not exist)") except for the droven crossbow: Obsidian is lighter in [weight](/wiki/Weight "Weight") than most [metallic](/wiki/Metallic "Metallic") materials, but is [fragile](/wiki/Fragile "Fragile") and shatters when [thrown](/wiki/Thrown "Thrown") or [fired](/wiki/Fired "Fired") unless it is [fixed](/wiki/Fixed "Fixed"). The droven crossbow is made of [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver") and bears the holy symbol of [Lolth](/wiki/Lolth_\(dNetHack\) "Lolth (dNetHack)"), and all obsidian droven weapons in a drow hero's starting inventory will be coated in [sleeping](/wiki/Sleeping "Sleeping") poison.

Droven plate mail and chain mail are made out of [shadowsteel](/wiki/Shadowsteel "Shadowsteel"): shadowsteel is even lighter than obsidian and other metallic materials and quite durable as armor material, but slowly evaporates with each step taken in a lit square until it is eventually destroyed, though the odds of evaporation can be reduced by a cloak that grants [magic cancellation](/wiki/Magic_cancellation "Magic cancellation") (with higher MC cloaks offering more reduction in evaporation chances), and fixed shadowsteel will even gradually auto-repair in unlit squares.

Droven cloaks are made of cloth woven from spiderwebs: they grant no base [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") but offer MC3, and can be [applied](/wiki/Applied "Applied") by a hero of any race to either create a [web](/wiki/Web "Web") on an adjacent square or remove a web from that square - creating webs decreases the cloak's MC by 1, using it up when it reaches 0, and removing webs with it restores 1 MC.

Due to being acclimated to life in the darkness, many drow heroes start with [shadowlander's torches](/wiki/Shadowlander%27s_torch "Shadowlander's torch"), which emit darkness rather than light; as noted above, any light sources such as standard [torches](/wiki/Torch "Torch") in a drow hero's starting inventory are replaced with shadowlander's torches.

### Lolth

- *Main article: [Lolth (dNetHack)](/wiki/Lolth_\(dNetHack\) "Lolth (dNetHack)")*

Lolth is the primary drow goddess. When [engraved](/wiki/Engrave "Engrave"), the name "Lolth" is a drow-specific alternative to [elves](/wiki/Elves "Elves")' full-power [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth") (i.e. vanilla [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") Elbereth). Like full-power Elbereth, it works on the vast majority of monsters, but not on [shopkeepers](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper"), [guards](/wiki/Guard "Guard"), the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor"), [blind](/wiki/Blind "Blind") monsters, [peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful") or [tame](/wiki/Tame "Tame") monsters, the @ [human or elf](/wiki/Human_or_elf "Human or elf") monster class, the [elder priest](/wiki/Elder_priest "Elder priest"), [Great Cthulhu](/wiki/Great_Cthulhu "Great Cthulhu"), [Chokhmah Sephirah](/wiki/Keter_Sephiroth#Chokhmah_Sephirah "Keter Sephiroth"), [Lamashtu](/wiki/Lamashtu "Lamashtu") and the [Riders](/wiki/Riders "Riders") (and any monster that revives like a Rider). Like Elbereth, it only has a chance of affecting some other monsters: it has a 1⁄2 chance of working on [Chaos](/wiki/Chaos "Chaos"), a 1⁄3 chance of working on [Demogorgon](/wiki/Demogorgon "Demogorgon"), and a 1⁄9 chance of working on [Asmodeus](/wiki/Asmodeus "Asmodeus"). Unlike Elbereth, Lolth *does* work on lawful [minions](/wiki/Minion "Minion"), [angels](/wiki/Angel "Angel"), and [minotaurs](/wiki/Minotaur "Minotaur"). The downside compared to Elbereth is that if the monster is higher level than you, it will drain your [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record"), and it won't work if it is 0 or less.

Lolth does not work in the future (i.e. in the [Anachrononaut quest](/wiki/Anachrononaut_quest "Anachrononaut quest")). Lolth also does not work for characters of gnostic (void) alignment, i.e. [Binders](/wiki/Binder "Binder").

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

*"Lolth also only works when following certain drow gods - detail which gods they are."*

### dNetHack strategy

A drow's light-blindness makes it all too easy to inadvertently attack pets and peaceful monsters, and their ability to create dark areas is often limited without the aid of other items. As a result, the first couple levels of the dungeon can be slow while waiting for power to recharge, and gaining experience will likewise take time.

In terms of starting inventory, droven weapons are high-damage but brittle, and should be handled with care; both droven crossbows and signet rings can be used against silver-hating hostiles in a pinch, and the sleeping poison for both rings and weapons can be fairly reliable in immobilizing particularly troublesome opponents that lack sleep resistance. Shadowlander's torches are a generally useful aid for quickly navigating lit rooms.

## EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), drow are considered an elven subrace similar to other variants: their starting attributes and caps are the same as other elves, they share an aversion to [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron"), and other elves count as the same race for purposes of [cannibalism](/wiki/Cannibalism "Cannibalism") and [sacrifice](/wiki/Sacrifice "Sacrifice"). Drow can play as either a [Convict](/wiki/Convict "Convict"), [Infidel](/wiki/Infidel "Infidel"), [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight"), [Monk](/wiki/Monk "Monk"), [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest"), [Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue"), [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger"), or [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") - with the exception of the unaligned Infidel, drow are always chaotic.

### EvilHack benefits and restrictions

- *For other qualities of drow monsters (including the hero) in this variant, see [Drow (monster attribute)#EvilHack](/wiki/Drow_\(monster_attribute\)#EvilHack "Drow (monster attribute)").*

Drow start with [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance") and [ultravision](/index.php?title=Ultravision\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Ultravision (page does not exist)") (allowing them to see in the dark as if it were lit), and they gain intrinsic [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") at experience level 5 and intrinsic [searching](/wiki/Searching "Searching") at experience level 9. Drow characters have a natural ability to move through webs effortlessly like spiders are able to, and can cast an aura of darkness via the #monster command for 10 energy as long as they are not impaired (e.g. [stunned](/wiki/Stunned "Stunned") or [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused")).

While drow in EvilHack can tolerate being in the light, they suffer various penalties while in a lit square: their [hit points](/wiki/Hit_points "Hit points") regenerate three times slower, spell power regenerates two times slower, and to-hit suffers a −3 penalty across the board. In dark squares, drow receive a ((XL/ 3) + 2) bonus [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") when using drow weaponry or attacking bare-handed. Drow racial armor and weapons are made of [adamantine](/wiki/Adamantine "Adamantine") (weapons and heavy armor) or [spider silk](/wiki/Spider_silk_\(material\) "Spider silk (material)") (light armor).

Most drow heroes start the game with a [large spider](/index.php?title=Large_spider\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Large spider (page does not exist)") as their default pet - Drow [Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight") start the game with the standard [tame](/wiki/Tame "Tame") and [saddled](/wiki/Saddled "Saddled") [lesser nightmare](/wiki/Lesser_nightmare "Lesser nightmare") for chaotic Knights, while drow [Convicts](/wiki/Convict "Convict") start with the standard tame [sewer rat](/wiki/Sewer_rat "Sewer rat"). Drow heroes are the only ones that can tame [spiders](/wiki/Spiders "Spiders") and [cave lizards](/index.php?title=Cave_lizard_\(EvilHack\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Cave lizard (EvilHack) (page does not exist)") using food and use them as [steeds](/wiki/Steed "Steed").

#### EvilHack attribute caps

| [Str](/wiki/Strength "Strength") | [Dex](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity") | [Con](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") | [Int](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") | [Wis](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") | [Cha](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") |
| -------------------------------- | ---------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | ---------------------------- | -------------------------------- |
| 18                               | 20                                 | 16                                       | 20                                       | 20                           | 18                               |

Drow share the same attribute caps as elves in EvilHack: they excel in mental attributes and are tied for the second-highest [intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") and [wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") caps at 20, and share the same high [dexterity](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity") cap of 20 with elves and many other races. While their [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") cap of 18 is still low, it is still fairly high in comparison to [hobbits](/wiki/Hobbit_\(starting_race\) "Hobbit (starting race)") (16) and [illithids](/wiki/Illithid_\(starting_race\) "Illithid (starting race)") (10). Similarly, their [constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") cap of 16 is second-lowest in comparison to the illithid's 12.

### EvilHack starting equipment

All drow heroes start the game with knowledge of drow items and the [potion of drow poison](/index.php?title=Potion_of_drow_poison\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Potion of drow poison (page does not exist)"). Drow have several replacements made to the starting equipment of their role which are listed in the table below, with bolded entries signifying the use of a separate starting inventory rather than a normal substitution:

| Standard item(s)                                                             | Replacement item(s)                                                                                                                                                          | Affected roles                                                      |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| [potion of sickness](/wiki/Potion_of_sickness "Potion of sickness")          | [potion of drow poison](/index.php?title=Potion_of_drow_poison\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Potion of drow poison (page does not exist)")                                        | **[Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue")**                                    |
| [dagger](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger")                                              | [dark elven dagger](/wiki/Dark_elven_dagger_\(EvilHack\) "Dark elven dagger (EvilHack)")                                                                                     | [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger"), [Infidel](/wiki/Infidel "Infidel") |
|                                                                              | [dark elven hand crossbow](/wiki/Dark_elven_hand_crossbow "Dark elven hand crossbow") [dark elven crossbow bolts](/wiki/Dark_elven_crossbow_bolt "Dark elven crossbow bolt") | **[Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue")**                                    |
| [spear](/wiki/Spear "Spear")                                                 | [dark elven spear](/wiki/Dark_elven_spear "Dark elven spear")                                                                                                                | None                                                                |
| [short sword](/wiki/Short_sword "Short sword")                               | [dark elven short sword](/wiki/Dark_elven_short_sword_\(EvilHack\) "Dark elven short sword (EvilHack)")                                                                      | **[Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue")**                                    |
| [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword")                                  | [dark elven long sword](/wiki/Dark_elven_long_sword "Dark elven long sword")                                                                                                 | [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")                                     |
| [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace")                                                    | [dark elven mace](/wiki/Dark_elven_mace "Dark elven mace")                                                                                                                   | [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest")                                     |
| [bow](/wiki/Bow "Bow")                                                       | [dark elven bow](/wiki/Dark_elven_bow_\(EvilHack\) "Dark elven bow (EvilHack)")                                                                                              | [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger")                                     |
| [arrow](/wiki/Arrow "Arrow")                                                 | [dark elven arrow](/wiki/Dark_elven_arrow_\(EvilHack\) "Dark elven arrow (EvilHack)")                                                                                        | [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger")                                     |
| [gloves](/wiki/Pair_of_gloves "Pair of gloves")                              | [dark elven gloves](/wiki/Dark_elven_gloves "Dark elven gloves")                                                                                                             | [Monk](/wiki/Monk "Monk")                                           |
| [gauntlets](/wiki/Gauntlets_\(EvilHack\) "Gauntlets (EvilHack)")             |                                                                                                                                                                              | [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")                                     |
| [armor](/wiki/Leather_armor "Leather armor")                                 | [dark elven tunic](/wiki/Dark_elven_tunic "Dark elven tunic")                                                                                                                | **[Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue")**                                    |
| [jacket](/wiki/Jacket "Jacket")                                              | [dark elven tunic](/wiki/Dark_elven_tunic "Dark elven tunic")                                                                                                                | [Infidel](/wiki/Infidel "Infidel")                                  |
| [plate mail](/wiki/Plate_mail "Plate mail")                                  | [dark elven chain mail](/wiki/Dark_elven_chain_mail "Dark elven chain mail")                                                                                                 | [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")                                     |
| [helmet](/wiki/Helmet "Helmet")                                              | [dark elven helm](/wiki/Dark_elven_helm "Dark elven helm")                                                                                                                   | [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")                                     |
| [small shield](/wiki/Small_shield "Small shield")                            | [dark elven bracers](/wiki/Dark_elven_bracers "Dark elven bracers")                                                                                                          | [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest")                                     |
| [large shield](/wiki/Large_shield "Large shield")                            | [dark elven helm](/wiki/Dark_elven_helm "Dark elven helm")                                                                                                                   | [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")                                     |
| [cloak of displacement](/wiki/Cloak_of_displacement "Cloak of displacement") | [dark elven cloak](/wiki/Dark_elven_cloak "Dark elven cloak")                                                                                                                | [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger")                                     |
| [cloak of protection](/wiki/Cloak_of_protection "Cloak of protection")       | [dark elven cloak](/wiki/Dark_elven_cloak "Dark elven cloak")                                                                                                                | [Infidel](/wiki/Infidel "Infidel")                                  |

## SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), drow heroes retain all applicable traits from SLASH'EM, with additional benefits, restrictions and changes listed below.

### SlashTHEM benefits and restrictions

Drow heroes can reach a minimum of Basic skill level in [saber](/wiki/Saber "Saber"), Basic in [musicalize spells](/index.php?title=Musicalize_spells\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Musicalize spells (page does not exist)"), and Skilled in bows. All other benefits and restrictions from SLASH'EM apply.

## Origin

The dNetHack implementation of the drow race is based on the drow of SLASH'EM, with the poison-injecting signet rings of the former being their answer to the latter's sleep-inducing melee attack.

## Encyclopedia entries

### dNetHack

Myths exist for a purpose - To explain the unexplainable.  
Because man fears the unknown.  
  
Murdering our kin. Our children.  
Butchering our towns.  
Devouring our flesh.  
Enslaving our people.  
Whispering of incest.  
Desecrating our lands.  
These mythical black demons with red eyes, embodying all  
the sins of men.  
  
But what if those demons truly exist?  
What are they, who are they?  
Do they dream?  
Do they hate and love?  
Do they have their own demons that represent  
everything they despise and fear?

\[ Drowtales, by Kern, Kite, and Bandit, Drowtales.com ]

Also known as dark elves, drow are a depraved and evil  
subterranean offshoot of the elvish species.  
  
White is the most common hair color among drow, but almost  
any pale shade is possible. Drow tend to be smaller and  
thinner than other sorts of elves, and their eyes are often  
a vivid red.

\[ DnD 3.5 SRD ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [monst.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 3757](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line3757 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/monst.c"): *drow have M2\_ELF flag*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [attrib.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 135](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/attrib.c#line135 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/attrib.c")

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")
html:
Drow (starting race)

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Contents

  • 1 SLASH'EM
    • 1.1 SLASH'EM benefits and restrictions
      • 1.1.1 SLASH'EM attribute caps
    • 1.2 SLASH'EM strategy
  • 2 dNetHack
    • 2.1 dNetHack benefits and restrictions
      • 2.1.1 dNetHack attribute caps
    • 2.2 dNetHack starting equipment
    • 2.3 Lolth
    • 2.4 dNetHack strategy
  • 3 EvilHack
    • 3.1 EvilHack benefits and restrictions
      • 3.1.1 EvilHack attribute caps
    • 3.2 EvilHack starting equipment
  • 4 SlashTHEM
    • 4.1 SlashTHEM benefits and restrictions
  • 5 Origin
  • 6 Encyclopedia entries
    • 6.1 dNetHack
  • 7 References

Drow, sometimes known as "dark elves", are a playable race of hero that appears in some variants of NetHack. They are most commonly implemented as a type of elf that are dark counterparts to standard elves, with a similar spread of attribute caps.

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

"dNetHack section still has stuff to sift through. SLASH'EM item subs as well"

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, drow serve as chaotic same-race counterparts to the elves:[1] the elves of SLASH'EM are usually lawful and can be played as lawful or neutral, as opposed to being chaotic like in NetHack. Drow can take the roles of Barbarian, Flame Mage, Ice Mage, Necromancer, Priest, Ranger, Undead Slayer, or Wizard.

According to the Guidebook:

Drow are the dark elves of the sunless realm. Well-suited to the dungeon environment, they have much in common with standard elves, but their specialty is their sleep attack.


SLASH'EM benefits and restrictions

For other qualities of drow monsters (including the hero) in this variant, see Drow (monster attribute)#SLASH'EM.

A drow hero engaging in bare-handed combat can sometimes put monsters to sleep, and like elves they gain sleep resistance at experience level 4.[2] Unlike elves, drow heroes do not have infravision and cannot be seen via infravision themselves, and they are also incapable of two-weapon combat.

SLASH'EM attribute caps

Str Dex Con Int Wis Cha
18 18 16 20 20 18

Like elves in SLASH'EM, drow excel in mental attributes and are tied for the highest intelligence and wisdom caps at 20, while their strength has the lowest cap at 18, tied with elves and hobbits. Drow are also tied with elves for the lowest constitution cap at 16.

SLASH'EM strategy

The drow's sleep-inducing bare-handed attack make them enticing for players new to SLASH'EM: during the early game, drow characters survive well if they know when to fight bare-handed, and can keep monsters asleep with repeated strikes - this also enables them to more effectively fight multiple opponents or flee into a corridor as necessary. Drow heroes with high bare-handed combat skill and fortunate enough rolls can even take down shopkeepers in hand-to-hand battles without taking a hit. The trade-off for this remarkable power is the lower damage output imposed by the inability to two-weapon, as well as the limits on attribute shared with standard elves.

A droven Barbarian is an easy race-role combination that allows the player to begin fighting bare-handed before switching to a better weapon like a battle-axe or an artifact weapon.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack, drow have several substantial differences from elves, when begins as early as starting alignment: female drow heroes start the game as chaotic, while male drow or "hedrow" heroes are neutral. The quest a drow hero undertakes also differs between genders as well, and is also dependent on their role.

Drow can take the role of Anachrononauts, Binders, Convicts, Healers, Madpeople, Nobles, Pirates, Priests, Rogues, Rangers, Troubadours, or Wizards.

dNetHack benefits and restrictions

For other qualities of drow monsters (including the hero) in this set of variants, see Drow (monster attribute)#dNetHack.

Drow can see perfectly in the dark, but cannot see into lit areas and are virtually 'blind' in the light: light-blindness is much different from ordinary blindness in that a drow hero can still see (and thus will not have intrinsic telepathy trigger), but can only see items and engravings directly at their feet, along with items in their own inventory. Drow heroes can create a patch of darkness using the #monster extended command, which costs up to 10 energy (or all of it if their maximum energy is below 10).

Drow heroes, and nearly all drow monsters except for any of the Changed, are generated as belonging to a particular "house" - this can usually be determined by the house symbols engraved on signet rings and heavy droven armor. Drow from houses that are aligned against each other will be mutually hostile, and will be hostile towards a drow hero of an opposing faction - conversely, drow of the same house, or of different houses that are aligned with each other, will be peaceful towards each other and towards drow heroes of allied factions.

All drow heroes can reach Grand Master skill level in bare-handed combat.

The default starting pet for a drow hero has a 2⁄3 chance of being a cave spider, and will otherwise be a baby cave lizard. Drow Healers instead start with a tame knight; hedrow Nobles start with a saddled small cave lizard, while female drow Nobles start with a saddled giant spider.

dNetHack attribute caps

Str Dex Con Int Wis Cha
18 20 16 20 18 20

Drow and elves share similar attribute caps, including boosted dexterity (20 compared to 18 in NetHack), but exchange their higher wisdom for higher charisma.

dNetHack starting equipment

Drow have several replacements made to the starting equipment of their role, and often have different starting inventories between genders - their starting inventory may also differ outright from that of other races playing the same role.

Standard item(s) Replacement item(s) Affected roles
robe droven plate mail Priest
athame droven dagger Wizard
dagger Noble, Ranger, Rogue
knife droven crossbow Pirate
short sword droven short sword Rogue
bow droven crossbow Noble, Ranger
arrow droven bolt Noble, Ranger
mace droven greatsword Priest (male only)
khakkhara Priest (female only)
buckler droven helm Priest
leather cloak droven chain mail Troubadour
apple tripe ration Knight, Noble, Troubadour
torch shadowlander's torch Ranger, Rogue
quarterstaff khakkhara Wizard (female only)

All drow heroes start with a droven signet ring, which is a randomized appearance for rings that allows the ring to function as a means of injecting poison poison-injection rings: when dipped into an eligible potion, the ring absorbs 30 doses of poison, which can be inflicted on opponents by attacking them in bare-handed combat while wearing the ring; if two signet rings are worn, both apply their poison. A drow hero's staring signet rings are pre-loaded with sleeping poison, and will always be of a valid ring type for their role. Signet rings also bear specific crests, sometimes including the silvered holy symbols of drow deities: rings that have a spiderweb design on them add +5 to unarmed attacks, while rings with holy symbols count as silver rings when attacking silver-hating monsters.

Droven weapons have higher base damage than most starting weapons, and are made of obsidian except for the droven crossbow: Obsidian is lighter in weight than most metallic materials, but is fragile and shatters when thrown or fired unless it is fixed. The droven crossbow is made of silver and bears the holy symbol of Lolth, and all obsidian droven weapons in a drow hero's starting inventory will be coated in sleeping poison.

Droven plate mail and chain mail are made out of shadowsteel: shadowsteel is even lighter than obsidian and other metallic materials and quite durable as armor material, but slowly evaporates with each step taken in a lit square until it is eventually destroyed, though the odds of evaporation can be reduced by a cloak that grants magic cancellation (with higher MC cloaks offering more reduction in evaporation chances), and fixed shadowsteel will even gradually auto-repair in unlit squares.

Droven cloaks are made of cloth woven from spiderwebs: they grant no base AC but offer MC3, and can be applied by a hero of any race to either create a web on an adjacent square or remove a web from that square - creating webs decreases the cloak's MC by 1, using it up when it reaches 0, and removing webs with it restores 1 MC.

Due to being acclimated to life in the darkness, many drow heroes start with shadowlander's torches, which emit darkness rather than light; as noted above, any light sources such as standard torches in a drow hero's starting inventory are replaced with shadowlander's torches.

Lolth

Main article: Lolth (dNetHack)

Lolth is the primary drow goddess. When engraved, the name "Lolth" is a drow-specific alternative to elves' full-power Elbereth (i.e. vanilla NetHack 3.4.3 Elbereth). Like full-power Elbereth, it works on the vast majority of monsters, but not on shopkeepers, guards, the Wizard of Yendor, blind monsters, peaceful or tame monsters, the @ human or elf monster class, the elder priest, Great Cthulhu, Chokhmah Sephirah, Lamashtu and the Riders (and any monster that revives like a Rider). Like Elbereth, it only has a chance of affecting some other monsters: it has a 1⁄2 chance of working on Chaos, a 1⁄3 chance of working on Demogorgon, and a 1⁄9 chance of working on Asmodeus. Unlike Elbereth, Lolth does work on lawful minions, angels, and minotaurs. The downside compared to Elbereth is that if the monster is higher level than you, it will drain your alignment record, and it won't work if it is 0 or less.

Lolth does not work in the future (i.e. in the Anachrononaut quest). Lolth also does not work for characters of gnostic (void) alignment, i.e. Binders.

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

"Lolth also only works when following certain drow gods - detail which gods they are."

dNetHack strategy

A drow's light-blindness makes it all too easy to inadvertently attack pets and peaceful monsters, and their ability to create dark areas is often limited without the aid of other items. As a result, the first couple levels of the dungeon can be slow while waiting for power to recharge, and gaining experience will likewise take time.

In terms of starting inventory, droven weapons are high-damage but brittle, and should be handled with care; both droven crossbows and signet rings can be used against silver-hating hostiles in a pinch, and the sleeping poison for both rings and weapons can be fairly reliable in immobilizing particularly troublesome opponents that lack sleep resistance. Shadowlander's torches are a generally useful aid for quickly navigating lit rooms.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, drow are considered an elven subrace similar to other variants: their starting attributes and caps are the same as other elves, they share an aversion to iron, and other elves count as the same race for purposes of cannibalism and sacrifice. Drow can play as either a Convict, Infidel, Knight, Monk, Priest, Rogue, Ranger, or Wizard - with the exception of the unaligned Infidel, drow are always chaotic.

EvilHack benefits and restrictions

For other qualities of drow monsters (including the hero) in this variant, see Drow (monster attribute)#EvilHack.

Drow start with sleep resistance and ultravision (allowing them to see in the dark as if it were lit), and they gain intrinsic poison resistance at experience level 5 and intrinsic searching at experience level 9. Drow characters have a natural ability to move through webs effortlessly like spiders are able to, and can cast an aura of darkness via the #monster command for 10 energy as long as they are not impaired (e.g. stunned or confused).

While drow in EvilHack can tolerate being in the light, they suffer various penalties while in a lit square: their hit points regenerate three times slower, spell power regenerates two times slower, and to-hit suffers a −3 penalty across the board. In dark squares, drow receive a ((XL/ 3) + 2) bonus to-hit when using drow weaponry or attacking bare-handed. Drow racial armor and weapons are made of adamantine (weapons and heavy armor) or spider silk (light armor).

Most drow heroes start the game with a large spider as their default pet - Drow Knights start the game with the standard tame and saddled lesser nightmare for chaotic Knights, while drow Convicts start with the standard tame sewer rat. Drow heroes are the only ones that can tame spiders and cave lizards using food and use them as steeds.

EvilHack attribute caps

Str Dex Con Int Wis Cha
18 20 16 20 20 18

Drow share the same attribute caps as elves in EvilHack: they excel in mental attributes and are tied for the second-highest intelligence and wisdom caps at 20, and share the same high dexterity cap of 20 with elves and many other races. While their strength cap of 18 is still low, it is still fairly high in comparison to hobbits (16) and illithids (10). Similarly, their constitution cap of 16 is second-lowest in comparison to the illithid's 12.

EvilHack starting equipment

All drow heroes start the game with knowledge of drow items and the potion of drow poison. Drow have several replacements made to the starting equipment of their role which are listed in the table below, with bolded entries signifying the use of a separate starting inventory rather than a normal substitution:

Standard item(s) Replacement item(s) Affected roles
potion of sickness potion of drow poison Rogue
dagger dark elven dagger Ranger, Infidel
dark elven hand crossbow
dark elven crossbow bolts		 Rogue
spear dark elven spear None
short sword dark elven short sword Rogue
long sword dark elven long sword Knight
mace dark elven mace Priest
bow dark elven bow Ranger
arrow dark elven arrow Ranger
gloves dark elven gloves Monk
gauntlets Knight
armor dark elven tunic Rogue
jacket dark elven tunic Infidel
plate mail dark elven chain mail Knight
helmet dark elven helm Knight
small shield dark elven bracers Priest
large shield dark elven helm Knight
cloak of displacement dark elven cloak Ranger
cloak of protection dark elven cloak Infidel

SlashTHEM

In SlashTHEM, drow heroes retain all applicable traits from SLASH'EM, with additional benefits, restrictions and changes listed below.

SlashTHEM benefits and restrictions

Drow heroes can reach a minimum of Basic skill level in saber, Basic in musicalize spells, and Skilled in bows. All other benefits and restrictions from SLASH'EM apply.

Origin

The dNetHack implementation of the drow race is based on the drow of SLASH'EM, with the poison-injecting signet rings of the former being their answer to the latter's sleep-inducing melee attack.

Encyclopedia entries

dNetHack

Myths exist for a purpose - To explain the unexplainable.
Because man fears the unknown.

Murdering our kin. Our children.
Butchering our towns.
Devouring our flesh.
Enslaving our people.
Whispering of incest.
Desecrating our lands.
These mythical black demons with red eyes, embodying all
the sins of men.

But what if those demons truly exist?
What are they, who are they?
Do they dream?
Do they hate and love?
Do they have their own demons that represent
everything they despise and fear?

[ Drowtales, by Kern, Kite, and Bandit, Drowtales.com ]

Also known as dark elves, drow are a depraved and evil
subterranean offshoot of the elvish species.

White is the most common hair color among drow, but almost
any pale shade is possible. Drow tend to be smaller and
thinner than other sorts of elves, and their eyes are often
a vivid red.

[ DnD 3.5 SRD ]

References

  1. ↑ monst.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 3757: drow have M2_ELF flag
  2. ↑ attrib.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 135

Droven weapons have higher base damage than most starting weapons, and are made of [[Obsidian (dNetHack)|obsidian]] except for the droven crossbow: Obsidian is lighter in [[weight]] than most [[metallic]] materials, but is [[fragile]] and shatters when [[thrown]] or [[fired]] unless it is [[fixed]]. The droven crossbow is made of [[silver]] and bears the holy symbol of [[Lolth (dNetHack)|Lolth]], and all obsidian droven weapons in a drow hero's starting inventory will be coated in [[sleeping]] poison. Droven plate mail and chain mail are made out of [[shadowsteel]]: shadowsteel is even lighter than obsidian and other metallic materials and quite durable as armor material, but slowly evaporates with each step taken in a lit square until it is eventually destroyed, though the odds of evaporation can be reduced by a cloak that grants [[magic cancellation]] (with higher MC cloaks offering more reduction in evaporation chances), and fixed shadowsteel will even gradually auto-repair in unlit squares. Droven cloaks are made of cloth woven from spiderwebs: they grant no base [[AC]] but offer MC3, and can be [[applied]] by a hero of any race to either create a [[web]] on an adjacent square or remove a web from that square - creating webs decreases the cloak's MC by 1, using it up when it reaches 0, and removing webs with it restores 1 MC. Due to being acclimated to life in the darkness, many drow heroes start with [[shadowlander's torch]]es, which emit darkness rather than light; as noted above, any light sources such as standard [[torch]]es in a drow hero's starting inventory are replaced with shadowlander's torches. ===Lolth=== {{main|Lolth (dNetHack)}} Lolth is the primary drow goddess. When [[engrave]]d, the name "Lolth" is a drow-specific alternative to [[elves]]' full-power [[Elbereth]] (i.e. vanilla [[NetHack 3.4.3]] Elbereth). Like full-power Elbereth, it works on the vast majority of monsters, but not on [[shopkeeper]]s, [[guard]]s, the [[Wizard of Yendor]], [[blind]] monsters, [[peaceful]] or [[tame]] monsters, the {{white|@}} [[human or elf]] monster class, the [[elder priest]], [[Great Cthulhu]], [[Keter Sephiroth#Chokhmah Sephirah|Chokhmah Sephirah]], [[Lamashtu]] and the [[Riders]] (and any monster that revives like a Rider). Like Elbereth, it only has a chance of affecting some other monsters: it has a {{frac|2}} chance of working on [[Chaos]], a {{frac|3}} chance of working on [[Demogorgon]], and a {{frac|9}} chance of working on [[Asmodeus]]. Unlike Elbereth, Lolth ''does'' work on lawful [[minion]]s, [[angel]]s, and [[minotaur]]s. The downside compared to Elbereth is that if the monster is higher level than you, it will drain your [[alignment record]], and it won't work if it is 0 or less. Lolth does not work in the future (i.e. in the [[Anachrononaut quest]]). Lolth also does not work for characters of gnostic (void) alignment, i.e. [[Binder]]s. {{todo|Lolth also only works when following certain drow gods - detail which gods they are.}} ===dNetHack strategy=== A drow's light-blindness makes it all too easy to inadvertently attack pets and peaceful monsters, and their ability to create dark areas is often limited without the aid of other items. As a result, the first couple levels of the dungeon can be slow while waiting for power to recharge, and gaining experience will likewise take time. In terms of starting inventory, droven weapons are high-damage but brittle, and should be handled with care; both droven crossbows and signet rings can be used against silver-hating hostiles in a pinch, and the sleeping poison for both rings and weapons can be fairly reliable in immobilizing particularly troublesome opponents that lack sleep resistance. Shadowlander's torches are a generally useful aid for quickly navigating lit rooms. ==EvilHack== In [[EvilHack]], drow are considered an elven subrace similar to other variants: their starting attributes and caps are the same as other elves, they share an aversion to [[iron]], and other elves count as the same race for purposes of [[cannibalism]] and [[sacrifice]]. Drow can play as either a [[Convict]], [[Infidel]], [[Knight]], [[Monk]], [[Priest]], [[Rogue]], [[Ranger]], or [[Wizard]] - with the exception of the unaligned Infidel, drow are always chaotic. ===EvilHack benefits and restrictions=== {{for|other qualities of drow monsters (including the hero) in this variant|Drow (monster attribute)#EvilHack}} Drow start with [[sleep resistance]] and [[ultravision]] (allowing them to see in the dark as if it were lit), and they gain intrinsic [[poison resistance]] at experience level 5 and intrinsic [[searching]] at experience level 9. Drow characters have a natural ability to move through webs effortlessly like spiders are able to, and can cast an aura of darkness via the #monster command for 10 energy as long as they are not impaired (e.g. [[stunned]] or [[confused]]). While drow in EvilHack can tolerate being in the light, they suffer various penalties while in a lit square: their [[hit points]] regenerate three times slower, spell power regenerates two times slower, and to-hit suffers a −3 penalty across the board. In dark squares, drow receive a ((XL/ 3) + 2) bonus [[to-hit]] when using drow weaponry or attacking bare-handed. Drow racial armor and weapons are made of [[adamantine]] (weapons and heavy armor) or [[Spider silk (material)|spider silk]] (light armor). Most drow heroes start the game with a [[large spider]] as their default pet - Drow [[Knight]]s start the game with the standard [[tame]] and [[saddled]] [[lesser nightmare]] for chaotic Knights, while drow [[Convict]]s start with the standard tame [[sewer rat]]. Drow heroes are the only ones that can tame [[spiders]] and [[Cave lizard (EvilHack)|cave lizards]] using food and use them as [[steed]]s. ====EvilHack attribute caps==== {|class="wikitable" ![[Strength|Str]] ![[Dexterity|Dex]] ![[Constitution|Con]] ![[Intelligence|Int]] ![[Wisdom|Wis]] ![[Charisma|Cha]] |- |18 |20 |16 |20 |20 |18 |} Drow share the same attribute caps as elves in EvilHack: they excel in mental attributes and are tied for the second-highest [[intelligence]] and [[wisdom]] caps at 20, and share the same high [[dexterity]] cap of 20 with elves and many other races. While their [[strength]] cap of 18 is still low, it is still fairly high in comparison to [[Hobbit (starting race)|hobbits]] (16) and [[Illithid (starting race)|illithids]] (10). Similarly, their [[constitution]] cap of 16 is second-lowest in comparison to the illithid's 12. ===EvilHack starting equipment=== All drow heroes start the game with knowledge of drow items and the [[potion of drow poison]]. Drow have several replacements made to the starting equipment of their role which are listed in the table below, with bolded entries signifying the use of a separate starting inventory rather than a normal substitution: {| class="prettytable" ! Standard item(s) !! Replacement item(s) !! Affected roles |- | [[potion of sickness]] || [[potion of drow poison]] || '''[[Rogue]]''' |- | rowspan="2" | [[dagger]] || [[Dark elven dagger (EvilHack)|dark elven dagger]] || [[Ranger]], [[Infidel]] |- | [[dark elven hand crossbow]]
[[dark elven crossbow bolt]]s || '''[[Rogue]]''' |- | [[spear]] || [[dark elven spear]] || None |- | [[short sword]] || [[Dark elven short sword (EvilHack)|dark elven short sword]] || '''[[Rogue]]''' |- | [[long sword]] || [[dark elven long sword]] || [[Knight]] |- | [[mace]] || [[dark elven mace]] || [[Priest]] |- | [[bow]] || [[Dark elven bow (EvilHack)|dark elven bow]] || [[Ranger]] |- | [[arrow]] || [[Dark elven arrow (EvilHack)|dark elven arrow]] || [[Ranger]] |- | [[Pair of gloves|gloves]] || rowspan="2" | [[dark elven gloves]] || [[Monk]] |- | [[Gauntlets (EvilHack)|gauntlets]] || [[Knight]] |- | [[Leather armor|armor]] || [[dark elven tunic]] || '''[[Rogue]]''' |- | [[jacket]] || [[dark elven tunic]] || [[Infidel]] |- | [[plate mail]] || [[dark elven chain mail]] || [[Knight]] |- | [[helmet]] || [[dark elven helm]] || [[Knight]] |- | [[small shield]] || [[dark elven bracers]] || [[Priest]] |- | [[large shield]] || [[dark elven helm]] || [[Knight]] |- | [[cloak of displacement]] || [[dark elven cloak]] || [[Ranger]] |- | [[cloak of protection]] || [[dark elven cloak]] || [[Infidel]] |} ==SlashTHEM== In [[SlashTHEM]], drow heroes retain all applicable traits from SLASH'EM, with additional benefits, restrictions and changes listed below. ===SlashTHEM benefits and restrictions=== Drow heroes can reach a minimum of Basic skill level in [[saber]], Basic in [[musicalize spells]], and Skilled in bows. All other benefits and restrictions from SLASH'EM apply. ==Origin== The dNetHack implementation of the drow race is based on the drow of SLASH'EM, with the poison-injecting signet rings of the former being their answer to the latter's sleep-inducing melee attack. ==Encyclopedia entries== ===dNetHack=== {{encyclopedia| Myths exist for a purpose - To explain the unexplainable. Because man fears the unknown. Murdering our kin. Our children. Butchering our towns. Devouring our flesh. Enslaving our people. Whispering of incest. Desecrating our lands. These mythical black demons with red eyes, embodying all the sins of men. But what if those demons truly exist? What are they, who are they? Do they dream? Do they hate and love? Do they have their own demons that represent everything they despise and fear? |[ Drowtales, by Kern, Kite, and Bandit, Drowtales.com ] |}} {{encyclopedia| Also known as dark elves, drow are a depraved and evil subterranean offshoot of the elvish species. White is the most common hair color among drow, but almost any pale shade is possible. Drow tend to be smaller and thinner than other sorts of elves, and their eyes are often a vivid red. |[ DnD 3.5 SRD ] |}} ==References== {{slashem-7E7|offset=1}} {{variant-343}} [[Category:SLASH'EM races]] [[Category:dNetHack races]] [[Category:notdNetHack races]] [[Category:EvilHack races]] [[Category:SlashTHEM races]] [[Category:notnotdNetHack races]]
